Award.AwardTitle: Pilot: Expressing Dramatic Character in Dialogue: A Toolkit for Creative Exploration of Linguistic Style

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer games and other forms of interactive media have many potential benefits -- ranging from the educational to the economic. Games are used to educate in areas such as computer science, health care, and language learning, while game industry revenue is now larger than feature film box office receipts. But many subjects we would wish to teach, and many genres in which we would like to entertain, are fundamentally limited by current authoring approaches: in particular, the amount of character dialogue that must be hand-authored. This project will use what is known about the creative work of human authors together with advanced techniques from the field of "natural language generation" to explore a new approach to addressing this problem. In particular, it will integrate a new model of dialogue generation into an advanced tool for interactive story authoring, then evaluate the results when both expert and beginning authors work with the tool, giving us our first understanding of the promise of such techniques for enhancing the creativity of authors.

The need for a new approach to dialogue is pressing. For example, the forthcoming commercial game LA Noir has a script of 2,200 pages (roughly equivalent to 12 feature films). Producing this amount of dialogue is simply impossible for educational game producers, and is nearing the limit of what commercial producers can manage, yet games can only continue to grow in sophistication by having more dialogue. This research works toward a solution for this dilemma, opening the door to further educational development and economic growth, by enhancing author creativity through cutting edge computer science. In addition, this project will help develop broader understanding of the field of Creative IT, providing a case study of how the knowledge of creative professionals and scientists can combine to produce social benefits that would be impossible for either working alone.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interactive Story Systems, Computer games and other forms of interactive media have many potential benefits -- ranging from the educational to the economic. Games are used to educate in areas such as computer science, health care, and language learning, while game industry revenue is now larger than feature film box office receipts. Storytelling agents could be used for entertainment, but stories are often a persuasive medium, and storytelling agents could also serve as companions for children or the elderly.  Many subjects we would wish to teach, and many genres in which we would like to entertain, are fundamentally limited by current authoring approaches: in particular, the amount of character dialogue that must be hand-authored. This is even more challenging when we consider that in human storytelling contexts, the storytelling adjusts the style and mode of telling and even aspects of the content for the audience. Scripted approaches to telling stories cannot adapt to individuals or context. See the accompanying figure demonstrating some of the applications of this work for dialogue assistants or interactive agents.

This project applied insights from the creative work of human authors together with advanced techniques from the field of "natural language generation" to explore a new approach to addressing this problem. In particular, we developed and tested several different approaches to this problem. We first integrated a new model of dialogue generation into an advanced tool for interactive story authoring, then evaluated the results when both expert and beginning authors work with the tool, giving us our first understanding of the promise of such techniques for enhancing the creativity of authors.

In this part of the project we developed the SpyFeet game, running on an Android smart phone. The idea of this game was to get people out and about moving from place to place on campus in order to collect cues to solve the SpyFeet mystery, as illustrated in the accompanying graphic. We implemented the story on the phone and collected user perceptions of story interest and engagement when character utterances were varied automatically using natural language generation.

We then investigated several different approaches that would allow us to bridge between any type of story content to many different ways of telling a story using natural language generation. We developed methods for automatically learning narrative structure from existing stories and tested them for whether we could learn causal relations between events automatically. We also applied an annotation tool that produces a deep representation of a story called a Story Intention Graph based on the NSF-funded thesis work of David Elson at Columbia. See the Story Graph Representation figure.

We developed new algorithms and methods for mapping this representation  to the deep linguistic representations needed to produce variations in  dialogue and story telling. We showed that we ,can vary both the style of the story, and narrative properties like being told in first person, or third person, or using direct speech or indirect speech. The Startled Squirrel story gives one example of the type of content that we can repurpose from publicly available weblog stories. Such stories are created daily in the thousands.   A figure is included showing how we can vary the different renderings of the same content using both stylistic and narratological parameters for our natural language generation engine.

See http://mediax.stanford.edu/events/automatically-generating-different-re-tellings-of-stories for a talk we gave on this work.
